I know a few people from Jordan, and they #8217;re warm and nice but had different views about Pakistan before they actually talked to me (a Pakistani).

A lot of Pakistanis don #8217;t have proper formulated opinions about Jordan either but the ones who have either visited Jordan or know about it think that it #8217;s a nice place, rich in history and well Jordan is kind of famous for its mansaf. It #8217;s right of you to not form opinions about something you don #8217;t know much about. Pakistan is multi ethnic, and there are a lot of sects of Islam here but the population is about 97-98% Muslim.

I #8217;m writing this from experience, to instil the habit of praying: -do wudhu even if you don #8217;t feel like offering the prayer, just remain in the state of wudhu. -say astagfar repeatedly - if Arabic isn #8217;t your language, learn the themes or translation of the surahs you recite in the prayer - you can make a checklist for prayers each day -maybe start reminding your mother to pray before she even has the chance to remind you.

Throne of Glass series by Sarah J Maas is about a female assassin and it isn #8217;t dark so I think that might be the one she read. She should read Shatter Me series by Tahereh Mafi, Divergent, Red Queen by Victoria Aveyard.

I #8217;m a Muslim and I don #8217;t think that she was insulting the religion judging from what you #8217;ve said. The Quran says, #8216;there #8217;s no compulsion in religion #8217;. If you genuinely want her follow Islam then you can and should advice her related to it and explain to her why she should follow it (other than because you want her to support your bf) but you can #8217;t force the religion on to her. Also, I #8217;m not judging you but I #8217;m just telling you so that it may benefit you that in Islam it #8217;s forbidden to be in a relationship of that nature outside marriage.

By praying at fixed times, you #8217;re fulfilling one of the pillars of Islam. This is what makes Muslims different from the rest of the people, the prophet (pbuh) said, #8216;the covenant between us and them is the prayer #8217;. That is worship, you #8217;re worshipping Allah. When you bow down in prostration, you accept your insignificance and humbly accept Allah #8217;s greatness saying #8216;subhana rabbi al aala #8217;, that is worship. Also, according to some madhabs you can make your own dua in sajdah too. Also, when you truly connect (which we should) you #8217;re not just saying words, you #8217;re saying them because you believe them to be true or you mean them.

Sometimes you don #8217;t need to have motivation to pray but rather self discipline. It #8217;s hard to always remain motivated (though we should be) but we should remember that we need Allah, Allah doesn #8217;t need us.
